California.description: Required companies like Uber and Lyft to classify most independent contractors as employees, entitling them to minimum wage, overtime, and benefits.
measured_effects: Immediately challenged by Uber, Lyft, DoorDash; overridden by Prop 22 (64% vote) for gig companies
Non-gig industries (trucking, freelance journalists) saw wage gains and increased employer costs
Estimated 100,000+ workers moved to employee status in non-exempt sectors
lessons: Contractor reclassification is politically viable in limited sectors
Platform companies can mobilize ballot measures to carve out exemptions
Enforcement infrastructure is critical; legislation alone is insufficient

California.description: Phased statewide minimum wage increase from $10 to $15/hr, implemented over 6 years with regional variations.
measured_effects: Low-wage workers earned ~$4,000 more annually by 2022 (UC Berkeley)
Restaurant employment did not significantly decline statewide
SNAP enrollment fell 15% in counties with early adoption
Fast-food sector faced higher costs; some automation investment accelerated
lessons: Phased increases reduce business disruption vs. sudden jumps
Effect on employment was neutral to slightly positive in large metro areas
Low-income households saw real purchasing power gains; Gini improvement modest

California.description: Capped property taxes at 1% of assessed value with maximum 2% annual increase, effectively freezing valuations for long-term owners.
measured_effects: Saved long-term homeowners ~$528B cumulatively by 2018
Concentrated wealth in existing homeowners; renters and new buyers disadvantaged
K-12 school funding dropped from 1st to 27th nationally within 10 years
Creates $12B annual tax cliff between identical adjacent properties
lessons: Tax restrictions designed for middle class primarily benefit wealthy long-term owners
Education underfunding from property tax cuts correlates with wage stagnation 20 years later
Hard to reverse politically once entrenched beneficiaries exist

California.description: California created its own refundable Earned Income Tax Credit layered on top of the federal EITC, targeting households earning under $30,000.
measured_effects: 1.5M families received credits totaling $1.4B in 2022
Working-poor households saw ~$1,200 average annual benefit
Child food insecurity fell 18% in high-participation counties
Healthcare utilization improved as disposable income rose
lessons: State-level EITC complements federal EITC effectively for very low-income workers
Direct income support achieves faster poverty-rate improvement than trickle-down
Cost-effective: $1 in EITC generates $1.50–$2 in local economic activity

California.description: Legalized duplexes and lot splits statewide, overriding local single-family zoning to increase housing supply in high-cost areas.
measured_effects: Implementation slow; many cities added restrictive conditions limiting uptake
Economists project 700K additional units over 10 years at full adoption
Cities near transit corridors saw more uptake than rural areas
Impact on affordability minimal in short term due to slow permitting
lessons: Supply reforms need streamlined permitting to have impact; zoning reform alone insufficient
Local implementation fidelity is the critical bottleneck for state housing law
Wealth inequality in housing requires both supply AND demand (subsidy) solutions

New York.description: 1M+ NYC apartments subject to rent stabilization laws limiting annual increases; rent control for pre-1974 buildings.
measured_effects: Existing tenants in controlled units saved ~$600/month vs. market rate
Reduced housing mobility: tenants stay 2× longer, reducing labor market flexibility
Unregulated market rents inflated 40–60% faster as supply constrained
Landlord disinvestment in stabilized units led to deteriorating stock
lessons: Rent control protects current tenants but worsens affordability for newcomers
Works best combined with aggressive new supply construction
Without supply expansion, price controls shift the crisis to unregulated sectors

New York.policy: NY EITC + Child Tax Credit Expansion
New York.description: New York expanded its state EITC to 30% of federal credit and created an Empire State Child Credit of $330 per child.
measured_effects: 750,000 families received average of $1,100 in combined EITC credits
Child poverty declined 4.3 percentage points over 6 years
Strong take-up in high-poverty areas (Bronx, Buffalo, Rochester)
lessons: Stacking state + federal credits creates meaningful income floor for working families
Per-child credits especially effective in high-cost urban areas

New York.description: NYC offered Amazon $3B in tax incentives for a 25,000-job campus. Community opposition led Amazon to withdraw.

after.actual_outcome: Amazon withdrew; LIC still gentrifying independently

measured_effects: Short-term property values in LIC fell ~5% after withdrawal then rebounded
NYC missed projected $27B in tax revenue over 25 years
Demonstrated power of community organizing over corporate subsidy politics
lessons: Tax incentive megadeals can backfire if community displacement concerns not addressed
Corporate job creation without affordable housing guarantees accelerates inequality
Negotiated community benefit agreements should precede large incentive packages

New York.description: Raised top marginal income tax rate to 10.9% for incomes over $25M, highest state rate in the US, generating revenue for social programs.
measured_effects: Generated ~$4B additional revenue in FY2022 used for schools and healthcare
High-income migration to FL/TX may account for 1–2% of high earners (debated)
Funded universal pre-K expansion in NYC and rural school aid
lessons: State-level high earner taxes generate significant revenue without broad out-migration
Revenue earmarking for visible services reduces political backlash
Migration effects are real but modest compared to revenue gains

Texas.policy: No State Income Tax + Enterprise Zones
Texas.description: Texas has no state income tax, funded by high property/sales taxes. Enterprise zones offer tax incentives for business relocation to low-income areas.
measured_effects: Texas GDP grew 92% from 2010–2023, fastest of large states
High job creation concentrated in metro areas; rural Texas saw minimal benefit
Bottom 20% pay 12% of income in taxes vs. 3.5% for top 1% (regressive structure)
School funding crisis: per-pupil spending 38th nationally despite property wealth
lessons: No-income-tax model generates growth but concentrates gains at top; Gini remains high
Regressive tax structure harms low-income households disproportionately
Growth without redistribution mechanism leaves poverty rates elevated

Texas.description: Governor-controlled $500M fund offering direct grants to recruit companies to Texas; dubbed 'deal-closing fund.'
measured_effects: Attracted major employers (Apple, Tesla factories, Oracle HQ)
Cost-benefit audits found 40% of jobs would have come anyway (deadweight loss)
Benefits concentrated in high-skilled, high-wage roles; minimal impact on Gini
lessons: Selective corporate incentives create headline jobs but don't improve inequality
Benefits predominantly reach high-wage workers, leaving low-income communities behind
Transparent accountability and clawback provisions improve program effectiveness

Texas.description: Texas is one of 10 states that did not expand Medicaid under the ACA, leaving ~1.5M low-income adults in a coverage gap.
measured_effects: ~1.5M Texans remain in coverage gap (income too high for Medicaid, too low for ACA subsidies)
Rural hospital closures accelerated: 25+ hospitals closed 2010–2023
Medical debt is leading cause of personal bankruptcy in Texas
Foregone federal dollars: ~$10B/yr in Medicaid match Texas has not claimed
lessons: Healthcare non-expansion concentrates medical debt in low-income households, worsening wealth gap
Rural hospital loss from low reimbursement creates healthcare deserts perpetuating economic decline
States that expanded Medicaid saw 5–10% improvements in low-income household financial health
sources: TX Dept of State Health Services

Mississippi.description: Passed phased elimination of state income tax, projected to fully eliminate by 2032, modeled after Texas/Florida approach.
measured_effects: Mississippi has highest poverty rate in US (19.4%) and lowest median income ($46K)
Income tax elimination disproportionately benefits top earners; bottom 40% see <$200/yr savings
Similar policy in Kansas (2012) led to fiscal crisis, reversed 5 years later
lessons: Income tax elimination in high-poverty states risks starving essential services used by the poor
Kansas experiment (2012–2017) is cautionary: budget shortfalls led to school funding cuts
Revenue-neutral tax reform requires offsetting consumption taxes which hit low earners harder
sources: Center on Budget and Policy Priorities

Mississippi.description: Federal and state investment in HBCUs including Alcorn State and Jackson State, aimed at closing racial wealth gap through education.
measured_effects: HBCU graduates earn 32% more than non-HBCU Black graduates from same income background
Jackson area shows strongest correlation between HBCU expansion and Black entrepreneurship
Economic multiplier: each HBCU graduate contributes ~$1.4M to state GDP over career
lessons: Education investment with targeted inclusion is strongest long-term wealth gap intervention
HBCUs outperform PWIs for Black student social mobility in high-poverty states
Sustained multi-decade investment required; results lag 10–20 years

Massachusetts.description: Enacted near-universal state health coverage using individual mandate, Medicaid expansion, and subsidized exchange — forerunner to ACA.
measured_effects: Uninsured rate fell from 6.3% to 2.5%, lowest in the nation
Medical bankruptcies dropped ~40% within 5 years
Low-income households' financial health improved markedly (less debt, more savings)
Cost per capita comparable to other New England states; no fiscal crisis
lessons: State-level universal coverage is achievable and fiscally sustainable
Combination of individual mandate + subsidies + employer requirements achieves near-universal coverage
Healthcare security directly improves low-income household wealth accumulation

Massachusetts.description: State committed $1B over 10 years to subsidize life sciences industry through R&D tax credits, facility grants, and workforce training.
measured_effects: Industry doubled to 120,000 jobs in 15 years
Average sector salary $115K vs. state median $89K
But: gains concentrated in Boston/Cambridge; rural MA saw minimal benefit
Skills mismatch: 40% of positions require advanced degrees unavailable to low-income workers
lessons: High-skill industry investment creates wealth but widens education-based inequality without inclusion pathways
Workforce training pipelines from community colleges must be co-developed with industry investment
Geographic concentration of economic development deepens urban-rural divide

Massachusetts.description: Ballot initiative added 4% surtax on incomes over $1M, dedicated to education and transportation funding.
measured_effects: Raised $1.8B in first year, exceeding $1B projection
Funded free community college for residents earning under $75K
Some high-earner out-migration: 2–3% relocation to NH/FL (early estimates)
Education and transportation spending increased immediately
lessons: Dedicated millionaire surtax revenue is politically durable when clearly earmarked
Higher-income migration is real but modest; revenue gains far outweigh migration losses
Education investment tied to millionaire tax creates visible equity narrative

Washington.description: Seattle phased in $15/hr minimum wage starting 2015, reaching $15 for large employers by 2017 and small employers by 2019.
measured_effects: University of Washington study: low-wage workers earned +$1,100/yr after increase
Food service employment remained stable; some shift toward full-time hours
UW 2017 study found hours reduction initially; later work showed income gains net positive
Broader regional effect: surrounding counties also raised wages to compete
lessons: Minimum wage increases in high-cost cities deliver net income gains to low-wage workers
Hours reduction is a transitional effect; annual income impact is positive
Phased implementation gives businesses time to adjust

Washington.policy: WA State Income Tax Ban (Constitutional Prohibition)
Washington.description: State constitution interpreted to prohibit graduated income tax; multiple ballot measures to change have failed. Funded by sales + B&O taxes.
measured_effects: Washington has one of most regressive tax systems nationally
Bottom 20% pay 4× their income share in taxes vs. top 1%
Despite high tech-sector growth, poverty rate 9.5% and wealth inequality high in rural areas
Repeated ballot measures for capital gains or income tax have failed
lessons: Reliance on sales taxes makes states highly dependent on consumption and regresses income distribution
Tech-sector growth in no-income-tax states concentrates wealth without redistribution mechanism
Narrow capital gains taxes ($262M in WA 2023) can partially offset regressive structure

Michigan.description: Detroit filed Chapter 9 bankruptcy ($18B debt), restructuring pension obligations and city services in the largest US municipal bankruptcy.
measured_effects: Downtown business district revitalized; 15,000 new jobs in tech/creative
Pensioners took 4.5% cut; inequality between pensioners and creditors stoked resentment
Surrounding neighborhoods saw minimal investment benefit; concentrated in ~2 sq miles
Blight demolition: 20,000 abandoned structures removed, reducing crime 15%
lessons: Bankruptcy restructuring enables fiscal recovery but distributes costs to vulnerable populations
Urban revitalization without geographic equity reinforces neighborhood-level inequality
De-industrialization requires 20+ year horizon; no short-term policy fully compensates

Michigan.description: Reformed nation's only unlimited PIP no-fault system; gave drivers choice of coverage level, lowering mandatory premiums.
measured_effects: Detroit premiums dropped ~40%; uninsured driving declined
Providers saw revenue decline; concerns over long-term injury coverage adequacy
Low-income households regained vehicle access, improving employment reachability
lessons: Mandatory cost reductions improve participation among those with constrained budgets
Auto access directly correlates with employment opportunity in non-transit cities
Regulatory reform can be a wealth-distribution tool in high-cost mandatory services

Oregon.description: Decriminalized possession of small amounts of all drugs; redirected cannabis tax revenue to addiction recovery clinics.
measured_effects: Overdose deaths tripled from 280 (2020) to 956 (2023)
Recovery clinic infrastructure was not built before decriminalization took effect
Police unable to compel treatment without criminal leverage
Legislature reversed decriminalization in 2024 after failure
lessons: Decriminalization without pre-built treatment infrastructure accelerates harm
Sequencing matters: infrastructure must precede enforcement removal
Policy rollout timelines must match capability development timelines

Oregon.policy: Portland Inclusionary Zoning (IZ) with Affordability Mandates
Oregon.description: Required residential buildings of 20+ units to include 20% affordable units (at 80% AMI) or pay into affordable housing fund.
measured_effects: Market-rate residential permits dropped 23% in first year after mandate
Developers chose 'in-lieu' payment over building affordable units in 60% of cases
Fund generated $24M for dedicated affordable housing projects
Net affordable units lower than pre-IZ pipeline due to overall permit decline
lessons: Inclusionary zoning can suppress overall supply if compliance cost is too high
In-lieu fee alternative may be more efficient than on-site unit mandates
Affordable housing goals require parallel public construction, not just private mandates

National.description: Reduced corporate tax rate from 35% to 21%, cut individual income taxes, doubled standard deduction, capped SALT deductions at $10K.
measured_effects: Corporate profits hit record highs; S&P 500 returned 55% in 3 years post-TCJA
Business investment increased modestly (~2% above trend)
Worker wages did not broadly increase; share buybacks > wage growth 5:1
Gini coefficient continued rising; TCJA had no measurable reduction in poverty
lessons: Corporate tax cuts primarily transfer wealth to shareholders, not workers
Supply-side tax policy is ineffective at reducing inequality
SALT cap disproportionately harmed high-tax Democratic states (CA, NY, NJ)

National.policy: American Rescue Plan – Child Tax Credit Expansion
National.description: Expanded Child Tax Credit to $3,000/child ($3,600 under 6), made fully refundable and paid monthly, for calendar year 2021.
measured_effects: Child poverty fell from 14.2% to 5.2% — single largest 1-year poverty decline in US history
39M families received monthly payments averaging $430/month
Food insufficiency among families with children fell 25% in 6 months
Expired December 2021; child poverty rebounded to 12.4% by 2022
lessons: Direct income transfer is the fastest proven mechanism for poverty reduction
Expiration effect proves sustainability requires permanent authorization
Monthly payment structure superior to annual lump sum for household stability
